segments.text: Now, repeat the last part about New York.
You'd have...
Okay.

There's absolutely no chance of finding oil in Long Island Sound or even as much as until 30 or 40 miles seaward of Long Island itself because the geology of Long Island Sound area consists of 200 or 300 feet of glacial overburden that overlies pre-Cambrian rocks.
which there's no oil that's ever been found pre-Cambrian rock.
And the oil company in their right mind would think of drilling a well in Long Island Sound for those reasons.

And yet the people on the Connecticut and New York shores and on the North Shore of Long Island were quite vehement in saying they don't want these damn oil rigs in Long Island Sound getting in the way of their sailboats or motorboats or spilling oil all over the place and messing things up.
And it's totally unrealistic to expect to find oil in that area.
I cite that as an example of emotionalism rather than back to objectivity.
Do you foresee more cooperation between, let's say, laboratories and schools and industries now that the desperation for new fuel sources has appeared?
Oh, I don't know.
I think cooperation, collaboration between the laboratories and industry has always been pretty good.
Let's see whether there necessarily should be more.
I think it will continue on at least at the same rate.
You don't see then, let's say, a proliferation of agencies involved in the ocean, which will mean an ocean-related activity, which will mean then...
duplication of research and research interest.
Yeah, we've already had that proliferation.
And these outfits have been messing all along, like BLM and EPA and the Marine branch of the USGS.
There are three that are now getting in the act.
We've already had the proliferation.
I hope to God it doesn't continue.
It would be even worse.
You foresee then, let's say, a new president's commission appearing.
Yes, as a matter of fact, I only foresee it, but Senator Hollings has already been making noises about setting one up in some of his more recent press releases.
And I reminded the staff when I saw that that you should go back and look at the one that came out in 1968.
Save the money for a new commission and apply it to doing more work in oceanography.
The blueprint's there if you want to follow it.
There hasn't been that much change
basically in sociology or anything else of economics since then have warranted a new approach or a new attack.
Do you see a changing direction in the future of research in oceanography?
Yeah, I think it's going to be directed more toward applied research rather than basic research, if you don't want to pin me down with a definition or two.

But right now there's more money available for oceanographers to solve problems on the continental shelf and estuaries and so on than there is in the deep ocean, because the people are tired of supporting
basic research in oceanography the last 20 years or more and not having anything very definite to show for it.
And so Congress reacts to the wishes of their constituents.

I think any additional funding that's going to come in oceanography in the next few years will be in projects that are more closely tied to solving specific problems that are a benefit to the congressman's constituents than just giving a blank check to go out and do what they want to.
So more applied than pure research?
Yeah.
Emphasis is definitely going in, already started going in applied research.
This million and a half dollars I mentioned before, as far as I'm concerned, strictly 95% of that is applied research.
Do you see, let's say, more environmental or impact studies coming forth from oceanographers?
More of that, but I think also more getting information that will help
develop the potential wealth of the ocean.
In the academic world, do you see the breakup of oceanography departments once more or more consolidation towards oceanography departments?
That depends on the institution.
You can't answer that question yes or no like, have you stopped beating your wife?
I think it depends entirely on the philosophy of the institution.
In most institutions, I think they're away from a breakup.
They're trying to incorporate new divisions, such as I mentioned, where the emphasis is on applied oceanography and the emphasis is on estuaries and shallow water.
But in this particular university, the emphasis seems to be about breaking it up by having marine science curricula, activities, sea grant, and that sort of thing.
Rather than trying to put it all under the umbrella of an oceanography department, they're trying to put all marine-related activities on the campus under a separate umbrella.
And this isn't just A&M, but I think that philosophy is a minority rather than a majority.
This is an example of Oregon State.
was a department of oceanography until a couple of years ago, and is now a college of oceanography, or school of oceanography, rather.
University of Rhode Island is a graduate school of oceanography.
University of Miami has a school of oceanography and atmospheric sciences.
So the emphasis, with only a few exceptions, is on consolidation rather than fragmentation.
I mean, I've been making comments about the government fragmenting and proliferating its oceanographic agencies and marine-oriented agencies.
I mean, the same applies to this university.
The last and final question, then.
Would you want to list people whom you would suggest had a shaking influence on your career in oceanography and say possibly a few words about them?
who had to direct you towards research oceanography.

Well, I already mentioned earlier, this afternoon, people like Dr. Hess, who was one of the first land-type geophysicists and geologists to go to sea and get information, George Willard, Maurice Ewing, Columbus Islin.
I guess those are the main ones.
Would you offer any explanation why that you were attracted to oceanography and working the sea, let's say, rather than work on the land?

Yeah, I think I mentioned that in the first few minutes, that I found out pretty soon working on land that the major questions such as continental drift and things like that couldn't be answered on land.
You had to get the information from the sea, where it, again, wasn't buried under thousands of feet of sediment.
This is for pure science.
I mean, applied science, of course.
Again, when the oil companies started going into the sea, well, I followed them along with it.
Well, does there seem to be to you a general, let's say, description of the older oceanographers, as people are quickly involved in the field?
They seem to have an interest in all sorts of environmental studies.
We're struck by the interest in the air and the ocean, for example, by Spilhaus, and the interest in continental drift and fields of magnetism and the ocean and you and other people.
Does it seem to be that oceanography and early environmentalist movements seem to work hand in hand?
Well, by environment you mean, well, it carries two connotations.
You talk about an atmospheric, a land, and a marine environment.
You know those three things.
OK. Rather than environment in the sense of an environmental impact statement.
Right.
OK.
I'll go along with that if you take it in the former rather than the latter.
And I think of the people I mentioned, including myself,
tend to be more generalists rather than specialists.
Now, this is the point being interdisciplinary.
This is the point we were leading up to, and we just didn't know how to ask you the question to get you to say it rather than us.
